introduction.title: Rust Introduction
paragraphs: Rust is a modern programming language.
It is designed for performance, reliability, and safety - especially safe handling of memory.

sections.heading: Why Learn Rust?
list: It is one of the fastest-growing programming languages in the world
Learning Rust makes it easier to pick up other languages like Java, Python, C++, and C#, because the syntax is similar.
Rust is very fast
Rust requires less memory compared to many other languages
Rust is used to build web servers, creating games, operating systems, and much more!

sections.heading: Difference between Rust and C\C++
paragraphs: The main difference is that Rust is "safe by default".
In Rust, memory access is automatically checked by the compiler, which helps you avoid common bugs like crashes, leaks, and unsafe memory behavior.
In C and C++, you must manually manage memory, which can lead to errors if you are not careful

Line 2: println!() is a macro, used to output/print text to the screen. In our example it will output "Hello World!". To end the code, you must remember a semicolon (;).

sections.heading: What is a macro?
paragraphs: A macro is like a function, but with an exclamation mark (!) after it.
Don't worry about the terminology for now.
For now, just know that macros are similar to functions (they execute things), but they do not always follow the same rules as functions.
You will learn more about macros later.

output.title: Rust Output (Print Text)
paragraphs: To print text in Rust, you can use the println!() macro:

sections.heading: Print Text with println!()
paragraphs: Try it Yourself »
sections.example: println!("Hello World!");

sections.heading: Multiple println!() Macros
paragraphs: You can use as many println!() macros as you want. Note that it will add a new line for each macro:
Try it Yourself »

sections.heading: The Print Macro
paragraphs: There is also a print!() macro, which is similar to println!().
The only difference is that it does not insert a new line at the end of the output:
sections.example:
print!("Hello World! ");
print!("I will print on the same line.");
sections.note: Note that we add an extra space when needed (after "Hello World!" in the example above), for better readability.
sections.tip: In this tutorial, we will only use println!() as it makes it easier to read the output of code.

sections.heading: Add New Lines Manually
paragraphs: If you really want to add a new line in print!(), you can use the \n character:

Just like with many other programming languages, you can use the newline character (\n) to break up lines. It is an escape sequence, and it forces the cursor to change its position to the beginning of the next line on the screen. This results in a new line.
You can also break up a line in the middle of a sentence. This goes for both print!() and println!():
examples:
print!("Hello World!\n");
print!("I will print on the same line.");
println!("Hello World!\nThis line was broken up!");

comments.title: Rust Comments
paragraphs: Comments can be used to explain code, and to make it more readable.
It can also be used to prevent execution when testing alternative code.
Comments can be singled-lined or multi-lined.

sections.heading: Single-line Comments
paragraphs: Single-line comments start with two forward slashes (//).
Any text between // and the end of the line is ignored by the compiler (will not be executed).
This example uses a single-line comment before a line of code:
sections.example:
// This is a comment
println!("Hello World!");

sections.heading: Single-line Comment at the End of a Line
paragraphs: This example uses a single-line comment at the end of a line of code:
sections.example: println!("Hello World!"); // This is a comment

sections.heading: Multi-line Comments
paragraphs: Multi-line comments start with /* and ends with */.
Any text between /* and */ will be ignored by the compiler:

sections.heading: Single or multi-line comments?
paragraphs: It is up to you which you want to use.
Normally, we use // for short comments, and /* */ for longer.

variables.title: Rust Variables
paragraphs: Variables are containers for storing data values, like numbers and characters.
To create a variable in Rust, use the let keyword and specify the name of the variable (name in this example):

sections.heading: Create a Variable
paragraphs: Try it Yourself »
sections.example:
let name = "John";
println!("My first name is: {}", name);

sections.heading: What is {}?
paragraphs: Rust uses {} as a placeholder in println!() to show variable values.
In the example above, the output will be "My first name is: John".
You can use as many placeholders as you like:

sections.heading: Using Placeholders in Order
paragraphs: When you use many placeholders, the values you pass are used in the same order.
In the example above:
The first {} gets replaced with name ("John")
The second {} gets replaced with age (30)
Important: The order matters. If you switch the values, the output will change:

paragraphs: By default, variables in Rust cannot be changed after they are created:

data-types.title: Rust Data Types
paragraphs: Unlike many other programming languages, variables in Rust do not need to be declared with a specified type (like "String" for text or "Int" for numbers, if you are familiar with those from C or Java).
In Rust, the type of a variable is decided by the value you give it. Rust looks at the value and automatically chooses the right type:

sections.heading: Type Inference Example
paragraphs: Try it Yourself »
sections.example:
let my_num = 5;         // integer
let my_double = 5.99;   // float
let my_letter = 'D';    // character
let my_bool = true;     // boolean
let my_text = "Hello";  // string

sections.heading: Explicit Types Example
paragraphs: However, it is possible to explicitly tell Rust what type a value should be:
Try it Yourself »
sections.example:
let my_num: i32 = 5;          // integer
let my_double: f64 = 5.99;    // float
let my_letter: char = 'D';    // character
let my_bool: bool = true;     // boolean
let my_text: &str = "Hello";  // string

sections.heading: Basic Data Type Groups
paragraphs: You will learn more about when you need to specify the type later in this tutorial.
Either way, it is good to understand what the different types mean.
Basic data types in Rust are divided into different groups:
list: Numbers - Whole numbers and decimal numbers (i32, f64)
Characters - Single letters or symbols (char)
Strings - Text, a sequence of characters (&str)
Booleans - True or false values (bool)

sections.heading: Numbers
paragraphs: Number types are divided into two groups: integer types and floating point types.

sections.heading: Integer (i32)
paragraphs: The i32 type is used to store whole numbers, positive or negative (such as 123 or -456), without decimals:
sections.example:
let age: i32 = 25;
println!("Age is: {}", age);

sections.heading: Floating Point (f64)
paragraphs: The f64 type is used to store numbers containing one or more decimals:
sections.example:
let price: f64 = 19.99;
println!("Price is: ${}", price);

sections.heading: Characters (char)
paragraphs: The char type is used to store a single character.
A char value must be surrounded by single quotes, like 'A' or 'c':
sections.example:
let myGrade: char = 'B';
println!("{}", myGrade);

sections.heading: Strings (&str)
paragraphs: The &str type is used to store a sequence of characters (text).
String values must be surrounded by double quotes:
sections.example:
let name: &str = "John";
println!("Hello, {}!", name);

sections.heading: Booleans (bool)
paragraphs: The bool type can only take the values true or false:
sections.example:
let is_logged_in: bool = true;
println!("User logged in? {}", is_logged_in);

paragraphs: You can mix different types in the same program:

constants.title: Rust Constants
paragraphs: Constant variables are used to store values that never change.
Unlike regular variables, constants must be defined with a type (e.g. i32 or char).

sections.heading: Creating a Constant
paragraphs: To create a constant, use the const keyword, followed by the name, type, and value:
Try it Yourself »
sections.example:
const BIRTHYEAR: i32 = 1980;
const MINUTES_PER_HOUR: i32 = 60;

sections.heading: Constants Must Have a Type
paragraphs: You must write the type when creating a constant.
You cannot let Rust guess the type like you can with regular variables:
Try it Yourself »
sections.example:
const BIRTHYEAR: i32 = 1980; // Ok
const BIRTHYEAR = 1980;  // Error: missing type

sections.heading: Naming Rules
paragraphs: Another thing about constants, is that it is considered good practice to declare them with uppercase.
It is not required, but useful for code readability and common for Rust programmers:
list: MAX_SPEED
PI
MINUTES_PER_HOUR

loops.title: Rust Loops
paragraphs: Loops can execute a block of code as long as a specified condition is reached.
Loops are handy because they save time, reduce errors, and they make code more readable.
For example, instead of writing the same line 10 times to print some text, you can use a loop to repeat it for you.
Rust has three types of loops: loop, while, and for.

sections.heading: Rust Loops Summary
paragraphs: Rust has three types of loops that let you run code over and over again. Each one is used in different situations:

sections.heading: 1. loop
paragraphs: The simplest kind of loop. It runs forever unless you stop it with break.
Use loop when you don't know in advance how many times to repeat.

sections.heading: 2. while
paragraphs: Repeats code while a condition is true. It checks the condition before each loop.
Use while when you want to repeat code until something happens.

sections.heading: 3. for
paragraphs: Repeats code a fixed number of times.
Use for when you know exactly what to loop through.

sections.heading: Extra Keywords
paragraphs: You can use these in any loop:
list: break - stop the loop
continue - skip a value in the loop

sections.heading: Next

functions.title: Rust Functions
paragraphs: A function is a block of code that only runs when you call it.
Functions are used to organize your code, avoid repeating yourself, and make your program easier to understand.

To call a function, write the name of the function followed by two parantheses ().

scope.title: Rust Scope
paragraphs: Now that you understand how functions work, it is important to learn how variables act inside and outside of functions.
Scope refers to where a variable is allowed to be used.
A variable only lives inside the block where it was created. A block is anything inside curly braces { }.

paragraphs: A variable created inside a function only exists inside that function:

sections.heading: Variable Inside a Block
paragraphs: You can also create blocks inside other code, like in if statements or loops.
Variables created in these blocks are only valid inside them.

paragraphs: In Rust, you can declare a new variable with the same name in the same scope using let. This is called shadowing:

This is different from languages that disallow reusing variable names.
In Rust, it's a feature used to transform or update values safely.

paragraphs: You can also reuse a variable name inside a new block:
Try it Yourself »

sections.heading: Why Scope Matters
paragraphs: Understanding scope helps you:
list: Know where a variable can be used
Prevent naming conflicts
Avoid errors when working with functions, loops, and conditionals
sections.note: Even though shadowing is allowed, using the same name too often can make your code harder to read. Use clear names when possible.

ownership.title: Rust Ownership
paragraphs: Rust uses "ownership" to manage memory in a safe way.
Every value in Rust has an owner. The owner is usually a variable.

sections.heading: Ownership Rules
list: Each value has one owner
When the owner goes out of scope, the value is deleted
You can only have one owner at a time, unless you borrow it (covered in the next chapter)

sections.heading: Basic Ownership Example
paragraphs: In this example, a owns the string. Then we move it to b:
When we assign a to b, the ownership moves.
This means only b can use the value now, because a is no longer valid.
Try it Yourself »

sections.heading: Copy Types
paragraphs: But simple types like numbers, characters and booleans are copied, not moved.
This means you can still use the original variable after assigning it to another:

Try it Yourself »

sections.heading: Clone
paragraphs: For other types, like String, if you really want to keep the original value and also assign it to another variable, you can use the .clone() method, which makes a copy of the data:
Try it Yourself »
However, if you don't need to own the value twice, using a reference (&) is usually better than cloning, which you will learn more about in the next chapter.
sections.example:
let a = String::from("Hello");
let b = a.clone(); // Now both have the same value

println!("a = {}", a);  // Works
println!("b = {}", b);  // Works

sections.heading: Why Ownership Matters
list: Rust uses ownership to automatically free memory when it's no longer needed
It prevents bugs like using memory that's already been deleted
It is one of the reasons Rust is so safe and fast

sections.heading: Next
paragraphs: Learn about borrowing - how to let other parts of your program use a value without taking ownership.

paragraphs: Borrowing helps you reuse values safely, without giving them away.

sections.heading: Arrays
paragraphs: An array in Rust is a fixed-size list of values, all of the same type.
You cannot grow or shrink an array after it's created.
To access an array element, refer to its index number.
Array indexes start with 0: [0] is the first element, [1] is the second element, etc.

paragraphs: When printing a single element from an array, use {}.
